posts.cooked: This is good news for us I hope we are ready for the whatsapp-refugees. And the instagram and the fbookMsgr refugees since those are getting merged w/ whatsapp
Finally! Hope this will convince some users to leave WhatsApp, hopefully get them on to Signal :). I presume that Facebook will use data from Facebook.com to display adds on WhatsApp?

frombeyondspace:

I presume that Facebook will use data from Facebook.com to display adds on WhatsApp?

They will surely also use Whatsapp Data for Ad Purposes.

I think it is very important to get a good strategy for using the unsatisfaction when the ads will roll out! It needs a clear communication, stating that Signal does not have ads and will never have. Since it has another Business Model, there is also no need to gather Meta Data or even Message Content.

MrShadowfly:

They will surely also use Whatsapp Data for Ad Purposes.

Hmm, what WhatsApp data are you talking about? Do you mean conversational data? That should theoretically be impossible due to the SIgnal protocol, right? I remember that there was an article way back that basically said Facebook could see WhatsaApp chat data because WhatsApp and Facebook app are part of the same app group, and sharing data between apps in a single app group is possible (see: No, end-to-end encryption does not prevent Facebook from accessing WhatsApp chats | by Gregorio Zanon | Medium) but I don’t think this was ever confirmed?

Or were you talking about metadata? I think that is a bit more difficult to use for advertising?

Anyway, I do agree with you a Signal campaign might be worth it when WhatsApp launches their ads. Not sure what the position of Signal Foundation is regarding this point.

link_counts.title: No, end-to-end encryption does not prevent Facebook from accessing WhatsApp chats

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
5_c_d:

This is good news for us I hope we are ready for the whatsapp-refugees. And the instagram and the fbookMsgr refugees since those are getting merged w/ whatsapp

Sorry to ruin the party, but they’ve had more than enough opportunities so far.

Signal nerd: But you said that as soon as ads comes you will leave wp
wp user: but it’s all about the status

Most people don’t even care about privacy. It’s always the same old story (so far without exception): “You’re 100% right, but…”

MrShadowfly:

… ads and will never have.

I wouldn’t believe that even if I said it myself. When someone asks me about Signal, I tell them the advantages (of the current state) over other apps/services, but I’ve stopped recommending “apps” (see also my comment Privacytools.io discussion to remove Signal from its recommendations - #28 by p4nci).

link_counts.title: Privacytools.io discussion to remove Signal from its recommendations

posts.cooked:
frombeyondspace:

That should theoretically be impossible due to the SIgnal protocol, right?

Facebook guarantees end-to-end encryption with WhatsApp. Anything else, no. Remember, backup data does not count into your personal Google Drive quota anymore. So theoretically, Facebook and Google could have a deal where the chat backup is uploading itself regardless of users’ settings. Or gathering intel through some other way, like reading notification API or keyboard API. All while the end-to-end part remains technically intact.

Also, having a Facebook account, you have your own personal Facebook ID, phones have GoogleAd ID…apps and phones many ways to gather intel about your “interests” apart from snooping on your chats. Huawei Mobile Services is contacting Facebook domain even without having Facebook app installed or having an account at all. So in essence, they are helping Facebook build shadow profiles of user on that particular phone number, without the user having a Facebook account in any sense (having no WhatsApp, no Facebook, no Instagram).

It is also contacting a dubious Chinese cloud. Huawei is not your friend. Neither is Xiaomi. They sell cheap phones, because they get the rest of the cost from your personal data. Just remember that when looking at the phones on the market. Cheap is not always the best. Especially so, when Chinese have this great Social Credit System. This means, their phones are adapted to that kind of socio-economical system and are vacuuming your personal data at any possible time.

Stay off the Facebook services and use firewalls at all times.

frombeyondspace:

Or were you talking about metadata? I think that is a bit more difficult to use for advertising?

Not difficult at all when you are a multi-multi-billion company with tons of programmers at your disposal.
They can combine metadata about who you texted/called and when/how often with your location, picked up by the FB app and any location sharing you may have done on WA, to pinpoint your interests and activities, then advertise accordingly.

IntentionalTypo:

Huawei Mobile Services is contacting Facebook domain

Intersting. I’m guessing that will cease now however, as FB surely will have to stop doing any kind of business with Huawei.

posts.name: f4bh33
posts.cooked:
I consider the following 3 variants for personalized advertising within the e2e application:

  • Linking the applications Facebook, Instagram and Whatsapp.
  • Creation of a local advertisement profile using on-device machine learning procedures.
  • (Mis)using of given permissions on the device (like location data, determination of installed applications, determination of activity times) in combination with the available metadata.
IntentionalTypo:

like reading notification API or keyboard API [Clipboard?]

Btw, here we go again:
https://community.signalusers.org/t/disallow-copying-backup-passphrase-to-clipboard-screenshot/7740/27

link_counts.title: Disallow copying backup passphrase to clipboard? screenshot?

posts.name: Jay Patel
posts.cooked: That will be good but people will need status like feature to migrate to Signal …

DonDino:

Intersting. I’m guessing that will cease now however, as FB surely will have to stop doing any kind of business with Huawei.

I’d be surprised, if that happens. Governments (or legislators?) should ban preinstalled Facebook services (or any sort of services) on mobile devices. It should be a free choice. Just like the browser thing on desktops. Completely naked Android.
Currently, even if you don’t have HuaweiID, the Huawei Mobile Services app (which can’t be disabled or uninstalled for a common user, only through ADB uninstall) is running in the background and sending all sorts of data to many domains. Mobile device also comes preinstalled with two facebook apks, Instagram etc. Legislators should take care of Facebook (probably) paying to telcos for providing mobile data subscriptions where Facebook traffic is zero-rated.

All of that, in my opinion, is very illegal and extremely unethical and should be taken care of in legal ways.

And all of that remote measuring “In what ways people use apps” should be prohibited through legislation, make it mandatory disabled and only as an opt-in choice for consumers, without penalizing them in any way regarding the usability of the app, if they don’t opt-in.

IntentionalTypo:

Legislators should take care of Facebook (probably) paying to telcos for providing mobile data subscriptions where Facebook traffic is zero-rated.

That’s not likely to happen in the current climate of anti-net-neutrality. Telcos are going the opposite way - actually providing plans for zero-rated access to specific apps, with the obvious deals happening in the background.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
frombeyondspace:

Finally! Hope this will convince some users to leave WhatsApp, hopefully get them on to Signal

Completely leave? I doubt it. I prefer Signal but I don’t see myself uninstalling WhatsApp.

I do see myself hacking WhatsApp on my device by killing its advertising services when they appear. And I see a market for hacked WhatsApp apk’s where the advertising code is sabotaged.
No one is going to care. Instagram has had stories ads for a while now and everyone still uses it.

Because there is not really an Alternative, is there?

frombeyondspace:

Do you mean conversational data? That should theoretically be impossible due to the SIgnal protocol, right?

They might access them before encrypting (keylogger-like). And since Whatsapp is closed source, you can not know, what they are doing or how encryption is implemented.

Furthermore I recently read an Article, saying that Zuckerberg or his Management wouldn’t mind weakening encryption for better ad linking. Don’t find the article anymore

p4nci:

I wouldn’t believe that even if I said it myself. When someone asks me about Signal, I tell them the advantages (of the current state) over other apps/services, but I’ve stopped recommending “apps” (see also my comment Privacytools.io discussion to remove Signal from its recommendations )

There simply is no need for ad in Signalapp. They are a foundation and do not need to make money for investors. And you know that their only selling point is Privacy. The Price of non-targeted ads is wayy lower than for targeted. If they introduce targeted ads, they give themselfes a headshot since its users care about privacy. And I do not believe that non-targeted Ads would make sense from a reputy/cost/value standpoint.

Herohtar:

No one is going to care. Instagram has had stories ads for a while now and everyone still uses it.

I just saw this (german) Article with a survey about mobile ads: Mindline-Umfrage: Nutzer sind von mobiler Werbung genervt - HORIZONT

They say that 76% prefer Apps without ads and 71% are very annoyed by ads on mobile devices.

link_counts.title: Mindline-Umfrage: Nutzer sind von mobiler Werbung genervt

posts.cooked:
MrShadowfly:

Zuckerberg or his Management wouldn’t mind weakening encryption

Mentioned over here == Contacts refuse to use Signal because it lacks many things - #89 by 5_c_d

Herohtar:

No one is going to care.

This is overly-pessimistic. I agree that we are not going to see whatsapp suddenly drop from 1500M endusrs to zero. But with numbers like that even a small shift in the way the populace views the product, can produce massive refugee-outflow. I think the lowest bound would be 0.1% unhappy people … aka 99.9% do not leave, or even think about leaving seriously enough to install another messenger side-by-side. But that is still a million-and-a-half people! What if a third of them install signalapp? +0.5M userbase for signalapp: means, more playStore reviews, stronger network effect, etc.

I think an upper bound of people that will be unhappy enough to try installing some competitor, is more like 2%. What if a third of those install signalapp? +10M userbase for signalpp, aka more than double what we have now.

johanw666:

I don’t see myself uninstalling WhatsApp. …I see a market for hacked WhatsApp apk’s where the advertising code is sabotaged.

Likely yes, but to me that is more opportunity for signalapp to gain refugees: there will be a lot of news stories in the rest of 2019 “facebook now overtly advertising in whatsapp omg!” and the associated churn on clickbait social media sites, and then during 2020 there will be a lot of “unauthorized apk shut down by fbook execs whoa!” stuff

Every time there is a bad-news-in-whatsapp-land story, we want there to be a good-news-in-signalapp-land story talking about some cool new feature getting introduced. We don’t need a massive advertising-campaign pushing “signalapp is very cool” we just need a steady stream of human-interest press-coverage… and ideally, somewhere in every bad-news-in-whatsapp-land story, a sentence or two saying “many endusers are trying out other messengers such as signalapp…”

But the key is retention. If they try out signalapp, but then decide ‘too unreliable / lack of features that are a dealbreaker for my use / will not install / will not register’ …that is how we can GET some refugee-flow, but fail to capitalize upon it.

MrShadowfly:

76% prefer Apps without ads

Right, exactly. And as long as signalapp has no adverts (check), and is easy to use (check), and is reliable-enough and feature-full-enough (maybe??) in time to attract and retain a significant chunk of whatsapp-malcontents, it will really help.

I strongly doubt this is the last bad-news-in-whatsapp-land news story, too :-)

link_counts.title: Contacts refuse to use Signal because it lacks many things
